author: Staff Reporter
text:
Youth spread message of care and love; no clashes reported

Members of Periyar Dravida Kazhagam flocked to the Marina on Sunday to celebrate Valentine’s Day —Photo: G. Sribharath

Youth across the city took part in a number of meetings to spread the message of care and love as part of Valentine’s Day celebrations on Sunday. On the other hand, a few organisations organised protests too. There was no report of clashes or any untoward incident anywhere in the city.

While several youths celebrated Valentine’s Day by hanging out in beaches and malls in the city, Knowledge Professionals Forum (KPF), an organisation comprising IT professionals, organised a programme calling on youth to celebrate ‘love beyond gender, caste and age.’

K. Seetharaman, secretary of KPF, said the forum celebrated Valentine’s Day by distributing pamphlets titled ‘Chennai for Love.’ The emphasis was on encouraging youth to transcend barriers for a harmonious society, he said. Members of Periyar Dravida Kazhagam proceeded to the Marina to celebrate the day and also ensure that couples visiting the beach were not harassed.

Members of the Students Federation of India (SFI) and Democratic Youth Federation of India (DYFI) distributed flowers to motorists, including families.

Members of Shiv Sena organised a protest meeting against the event in Pallavaram. G. Ramesh Babu, president, of the Tamil Nadu State unit, said Valentine’s Day was against Indian culture.
title: Celebrating an emotion, sending out a message
